subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking Allowed. Conversations
on the leading edge of knowledge and
discovery
with parapsychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Once again
I'm going to be interviewing myself.
I'm going to be
following up on the previous In Presence,
number 0215
for those of you who are particular
about the numbers.
In that interview with myself…
That's me. …we talked about
life after death and a particularly
interesting evidential case, one that was touted by William
James, in the first great textbook of
American psychology
as evidence for the spiritualist
interpretation of the self.
That case was known as the Watseka Wonder. It still stands today by many
writers of books on life after death as
an outstanding case providing
evidence for the afterlife. But
as you know, there's a problem with the
case.
The problem goes back to the great book
written by Frederic Myers,
published posthumously in 1903. I
know we're going to want to talk more about Frederic Myers,
as a matter of fact, because he—
after his death—began communicating.
The great book he wrote, of course, is
Human Personality
and Its Survival of Bodily Death.
This is a book that I think any
serious student of afterlife research
would want to have
in their library; if they can find
the Russell Targ edition published by
Hampton Roads, they'll notice
that you…. That's me. ...wrote
an interpretive introduction to the book.
Now, what did Myers have to say about the
Watseka Wonder case? Now we're getting
down to the meat
of the issue because, oddly enough, he
said this is
not necessarily a case that
promotes the afterlife hypothesis—the
survival of human personality after death hypothesis. He indicated it
as a case of pseudo possession.
Pseudo possession, not actual possession.
The reason he thought that might be
so was because there had been a lot of
research at that point in time, the late
19th and early
20th century regarding multiple
personalities.
The idea that Myers was really
referencing there is that the young girl,
Lurancy Vennum,
who supposedly had died or gone into
some sort of state of
remission of her personality and another
personality presented itself, that of a different child who lived
across town and who had died more than a
decade earlier named Mary Roff.
Myers thought it was
pseudo possession because he’s
suggesting that
really what happened here is
that the personality of Mary Roff wasn't
an actual surviving spirit of a deceased
individual, but was a secondary
personality of Lurancy Vennum
that had been suggested to her under
hypnosis by Dr.
Stevens and Mary Roff's father, who was
there on the scene
at the time.
What happened, basically, was a
secondary personality with extraordinary psychic gifts
who was able to therefore glean
information that would only have been
known to Mary Roff herself
or her family members, but not to Lurancy
Vennum who up until that moment had no contact with the Roff
family. What you have is a secondary
sub-personality
with psychic gifts masquerading
as a possessing
spirit of a dead child. That was the hypothesis that Myers put forward in his
great 1903 book, Human Personality
and Its Survival of Bodily Death.
Very interesting. Now, of course, such a
hypothesis
is sometimes referred to as super psi
in the literature. More recently, the term
living agent psi is preferred because
researchers say, we don't know the outer
limits of psi, why do you call it super psi? Super psi implies that we never
see this. But the interesting thing,
of course— and I'm fascinated by this idea— is that living people can exhibit as
much psychic
ability as the supposed dead, as a ghost,
as the deceased. So, let's just call it living agent psi.
Naturally, the fact that under hypnosis
it was, one might say, suggested to Lurancy Vennum in her condition that
the spirit of Mary Roff would come forth.
As one reads the accounts of the case, of
course, it seems as if
it wasn't suggested so much to her as it
came forth from her.
What happened was… Well, I'll let you tell
the story. Thank you. I'm happy to tell the story. What happened
was that under hypnosis administered by
Dr. Stevens, who had been brought
to the home of the Vennum family by Mr.
Roff himself.
As a spiritualist he was
concerned for
Lurancy Vennum. The rumors going
about the tiny little town of
Watseka, Illinois, that this child might
be sent off
to Chicago to an insane asylum where,
even though there might be some
semblance of care for her, insane asylums
in those days were like huge warehouses
for the mentally ill. I know because
I worked in a mental health facility in
Illinois after I graduated from college in Madison.
Those establishments…
I worked in a very modern one that was
replacing the outdated
gigantic warehouse institutions where
the mentally ill
were kept in the state of Illinois. So, it
was certainly an act of
compassion not to want Lurancy Vennum to have to spend the rest of her days
institutionalized
like that. So, Mr. Roff suggested that
a spiritualist doctor he knew,
Dr. E Winchester Stevens from Janesville,
Wisconsin,
should come and meet with the family and
maybe he could provide a cure.
He hypnotized Lurancy Vennum who was
having fits, who was
obviously very ill to the point
where
the family would lose their beloved
daughter and
would do so willingly because they
thought they had no other choice.
Under hypnosis
several troublesome entities or spirits
or sub-personalities, if you will,
appeared. Dr.
Stevens basically suggested to Lurancy,
“Well, it appears that you're
going to be controlled
by these other personalities, these other
spirits.
Wouldn't it be better for you if you had
a friendly spirit taking control?”
Lurancy, under hypnosis, said yes and
she began naming other spirits, in her trance state. In
her states of fits said she was going to heaven and talking to spirits and talking
to angels. She listed a number of
potential friendly spirits that might be
able to come and take possession of her
body. One of them was Mary Roff,
the daughter of Mr. Roff himself, who had
died earlier. Mr. Roff said, “That would be wonderful,
we'd like to see Mary,” and it was agreed.
In fact, as I recall, under hypnosis the
suggestion was that
Mary would return for a period of months
and then she would go away and Lurancy
would have her own
body back. Which is in fact
more or less what happened.
As I mentioned in the previous
discussion we had about this,
Lurancy, or you could say the Mary
personality, actually went and lived
with the Roff family. She understood
people by their nicknames, she expressed
affection for them.
She treated her biological parents, the
Vennums, with respect and
courtesy but she didn't have the same
affection. In fact,
she acted as if she hardly knew them.
That's why William James and the
researcher Richard Hodgson
and the people of the town
of Watseka, Illinois, I think were quite
inclined to the spiritualist
interpretation that even though it was
the body of Lurancy Vennum, it was certainly the spirit
of Mary Roff. Although, once or twice as I
recall,
Lurancy came back briefly. But basically
for three months Mary Ruff was the
dominant personality.
Obviously the case has weaknesses due to
the fact that
there was direct communication between
the Roff family and the Vennum family
prior to the appearance of Mary Roff.
The possibility of
suggestion under hypnosis, the
possibility of multiple personalities
that Myers favored can't be ignored.
But, it's worth pointing out that there are other cases of possession
of this sort. It's an extremely rare
phenomena. Maybe there are a handful of
cases, less than a dozen I think, of really
well understood, well-researched cases in
the annals of parapsychology and
psychical research, and I’m talking now
about 140
years of study of this phenomena. So it is uncommon. But nevertheless, there
are some good cases.
For example, the case of
Sumitra Singh and Shiva Tripathi.
Let's talk about that. This case
is a much more recent case. It really
started around 1985.
Sumitra Singh was a married woman,
she had children. She began experiencing
fits, she began going into altered states
of consciousness.
At one point she became very ill, she
said she was
about to die. It appeared as if in fact
she had died.
The family was preparing, I think, for a
cremation, a funeral, but then she was
revived. There are different accounts of
exactly how it happened.
This process may have gone on for
about a week.
But then at one point in
July 1985 she revived.
Only, when she revived she seemed to be a
completely
different person. Sumitra Singh
was basically a woman of very little
education. She could barely
read and write. She had never gone to
have any formal schooling. But she said
that her name
was Shiva and she said she had two
children named
Tinku and Rinku. She said that
she had been murdered by her
sister-in-law.
Furthermore, she seemed to be an
educated cultured woman
and she wanted to reconnect
with her original family, the Tripathi
family. She said she was Shiva Tripathi, although
Shiva was a nickname, her actual name I
believe was Arun.
This was in India.
The Singh family didn't know what to
make of this.
The new personality of Shiva
didn't even seem to recognize the
original family
at all. A period of about three
months elapsed before word of this
strange occurrence
reached the family of Shiva Tripathi, who
was an actual individual who had apparently
been murdered or was killed or committed
suicide, threw herself
into a train. Her body, I think, was
found
on the railroad tracks and it was cremated
quickly thereafter. The Tripthi family,
the family of Shiva's birth parents,
sued because they felt she had been
murdered. It was only some months
later that the rumor came that in
another village about a hundred
kilometers
away—60 miles—that
there was the apparent possession
taking place; that their daughter had
taken over the body of another woman and
was claiming to be their daughter.
They arranged to visit. As soon as they
visited she
hugged them, she kissed them, she treated
them warmly, she called them by their
nicknames, she wanted to see
her children to make sure they were taken
care of—which appears to be
a very important condition in not only
possession but reincarnation,
the need to come back, the unfinished
business that needs to be attended to.
The interesting thing about this
case as compared to the
case of Lurancy Vennum and Mary Roff,
is that there was no contact between the
two families
prior to the ostensible possession.
One couldn't attribute it to some sort
of suggestion
or hypnosis. Also, in terms of the evidentiality of the case
is the fact that it lasted for the rest
of Sumitra's life. I'm talking about
the body of Sumitra, because
Shiva, the personality of Shiva, the
spirit of Shiva remained in that body until she died in 1998.
In fact, when she first appeared she
indicated that
while she had been dead in the
realm of
the Hindu deities, of Yama and
the deities of death, they were
discussing and
said she died too early before her time
and they were finding a way for her to
return.
She announced at one point that she
would be around for another 10 or 12
years. I think
it was 13 years she remained
there. She stayed married to
the husband of Sumitra Singh,
Jagdish Singh, who lived another 10 years
after Shiva, or Sumitra, died in 1998. Jagdish died in
2008. An interesting thing about this
case is that
in around 2010
another set of researchers, Antonia Mills
from Canada, went back
and conducted additional research. This
case was heavily researched by
people both from the United States,
Canada and
India. It was well known in the
newspapers of India
at the time, as a matter of fact.
It appears as if the surviving
personality of Shiva
Tripathi remained in the body
of Sumitra Singh for 13 years
consistently.
Very interestingly,
in this case, as I mentioned earlier,
Shiva had a college education. She wrote
letters.
She clearly expressed
herself using much more sophisticated
language than the uneducated Sumitra
Singh.
In fact, the Trapathi family wanted to, in
effect, adopt the Singhs as their daughter, and they tried to find
work for Sumitra's husband, Jagdish
Singh. That didn't work out too well
because in India
the idea of a male
receiving support of that sort
from the in-laws was looked down upon.
Jagdish got a job because the
Tripathi family helped him out but
it didn't work out.
These people were doing basically
farm labor in the village where they
lived and then occasionally they would
travel to Delhi
and find other kinds of temporary
employment
when they weren't working in the fields
in their village.
So they lived, I think, a kind of marginal
existence. Shiva, who found herself married to a stranger,
was very uncomfortable. She'd
look at her body and she'd say, “This
isn't me. These people, they're not my family.” But she realized that
this is where she was and she accommodated to the circumstances
and even had two more children, as a matter
of fact, before she died.
When Antonia Mills
reviewed the case in 2010
she regarded it as a very strong case
supporting
the survival hypothesis. It didn't have
some of the weaknesses that one found in
the Watseka
Wonder case in terms of
the potential of hypnotic suggestion,
the possibility of multiple
personalities. Although,
if you were looking at it
skeptically you could say, yes, it was
a secondary personality with
extraordinary psychic ability,
you could say that. Now, one of the
wrinkles in this case of course is that
there was a question about Shiva Tripathi
having been murdered
by the family of Shiva's husband.
His name, incidentally, is Chhedi Lal Duetti, the original husband of Shiva Tripathi.
When Antonia Mills interviewed
Chhedi Lal Duetti about it, he said that
when he went to see
Shiva, who you could say reincarnated…
Sometimes this is called,
incidentally, a replacement reincarnation.
What seems to have happened in this
circumstance is that
Shiva came and bumped off the
personality, the original
personality of Sumitra Singh and
took over the body.
In some circles that's called a
replacement reincarnation.
Researchers have to acknowledge that
there's a fine line between
reincarnation and possession.
It's hard to exactly determine,
although in most cases it's assumed that
this is reincarnation, that the
person who died, died long before the reborn
person. But sometimes the death occurs
after the new person has
been born. The implication is
that the original
personality was… They use the phrase
“bumped out,”
and the new personality comes in. But in
any case, when Chhedi Lal Duettii
came to see his
reincarnated wife, let us say,
in the body of Sumitra Singh,
she acted as if she didn't recognize him.
The original members
of that family, the Lal Duetti family, were very
hostile to the whole idea that
they were being accused of murder.
Maybe rightfully so because murders of
this sort did occur
in India. There were well known cases of
murder in which a wife was murdered
in order that the family could receive,
I don't know, a larger dowry maybe from a
new wife
or something, or they were unhappy with
the size of the dowry. There were
numbers of cases, I think over a thousand,
two thousand maybe, such cases reported
in India
at that time and the Tripathi family
felt that this had happened. In fact,
when Shiva appeared in the body
of Sumitra Singh her first statements
were that she had been
murdered, that her sister-in-law had
crushed her head with a brick.
It seemed suspicious. The Tripathi
family immediately filed charges.
The body was cremated so quickly
that the Tripathi family didn't even have
a chance
to see the body before the cremation
occurred, even though they had requested
that a little time be given so that they
could
see the body. You have
my specialties here, a combination of
criminology and
parapsychology at work in this
particular case.
What do you think we can derive from
these cases of possession?
Why do they stand out as being
highly evidential of the survival of
human personality
hypothesis? There are two reasons: for
one, you seem to have an intact personality
that expresses itself
emotionally, it has the memories
of the original person, and there's
continuity. In the
Watseka Wonder case the continuity
lasted for three months.
Although that's short in comparison to
the Shiva Sumitra case
which lasted some 13 years,
it's still quite long when you compare
it to the kinds of
communications that occur during séances
with mediums, where
you will only have a personality
manifesting through a medium for a
matter of
minutes, or maybe in extreme cases,
hours. But when you're talking months and
years it does suggest that an intact
personality is surviving after
death. So you have both
the enormous variety of
expressions in the personality. For example,
Shiva in the body of Sumitra throughout
that 12-13 year period
expressed herself as a
college educated woman
not an uneducated woman at all. She
maintained that status, she insisted on being
referred to
as Shiva the entire time.
That was who she felt that she
was. There are other cases that have
lasted even longer. There's a case
we know of that lasted for some 60 years,
although the problem is that we were never able to identify the original
personality there. In looking at these kinds of cases it's very
useful to try and assemble as many of
them as possible.
And why is that? The reason is that
every case has its weaknesses but when
you see them all together the weaknesses of one
case may be overcome by the strengths of
another case. When you look at them
all together they seem to provide
a very strong case for human survival.
Especially when you
combine not only cases of possession and
reincarnation
and near-death experience and deathbed
visions and terminal lucidity
altogether, not to mention mediumistic
communications,
you begin to see quite a detailed
picture of what it means when we talk about the survival of human consciousness.
I expect that you and I will be
having many more conversations
about this topic. It really deserves a
careful look. It's understandable that
people are going to be
skeptical of the whole idea. I'm
skeptical.
The reason I'm skeptical and I think
the reason that many people are
skeptical is we don't want to deceive
ourselves.
The notion that we could survive the
death of our physical body is very tantalizing but the idea of
self-deception
is not very tantalizing, so I want to
examine the evidence
carefully. And I think that's the appropriate
attitude. Once again, I'd like to
thank you
for being with me. For those of you
watching and listening, I'd like to thank
you for being with us.
[Music]
